required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: The Effect of Coffee Consumption on the Serum Levels of Leptin, Folic Acid, and Vitamin B12
clinical_study.official_title: The Effect of Coffee Consumption and Body Weight on the Serum Levels of Leptin, Folic Acid, and Vitamin B12 in Young Males: A Cross-Sectional Study

brief_summary.textblock: The effect of coffee and body weight during the last 3 months on the level of leptin, folic acid, and vitamin B12

detailed_description.textblock:
Coffee consumption has been associated with several risk factors leading to cardiovascular diseases (CVDs), including hyperhomocysteinemia and hyperlipidemia. Frequent coffee consumption has beneficial effects in reducing the risk of diabetes mellitus (DM) type 2, obesity, liver disease, CVDs, some types of cancer, Parkinson's disease, and Alzheimer's disease. Controversies concerning coffee consumption benefits and risks in regards for CVDs were mentioned in many studies. Folic acid and vitamin B12 are necessary vitamins in homocysteine metabolism which is a risk factor for atherosclerosis. Leptin, is a hormone linked to obesity and it could be related to atherosclerosis.
The combined effect of coffee consumption and body weight on the levels of leptin, folic aid, and vitamin B12 is not well studied. In our study, we will study the effect of coffee consumption in males with different body mass indices to see the effect of several important parameters such as leptin, Folic acid, and vitamin B12.

primary_outcome.description: Plasma Concentration of leptin in ng /ml
Plasma Concentration of folic acid in ng /ml
Plasma Concentration of Vitamin B12 in pg /ml

secondary_outcome.description: Plasma Concentration of LDL, HDL in mg/dl

arm_group.description: Normal body mass index (BMI) / with moderate coffee consumption
Normal body mass index (BMI) / with heavy coffee consumption

intervention.intervention_name: Normal BMI and moderate coffee consumption
intervention.description: Normal BMI and moderate coffee consumption

intervention.intervention_name: Normal BMI and heavy coffee consumption
intervention.description: Normal BMI and heavy coffee consumption

study_pop.textblock: Young male students studying at Applied Science Private University (ASU) in Amman were approached for study participation.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- male,
- student of the Faculty of Pharmacy,
- do not have any acute or chronic medical conditions.
Exclusion Criteria:
- students who used any medications for either an acute and/or a chronic condition during the past 2 months prior to the study entry.

results_reference.citation: Grubben MJ, Boers GH, Blom HJ, Broekhuizen R, de Jong R, van Rijt L, de Ruijter E, Swinkels DW, Nagengast FM, Katan MB. Unfiltered coffee increases plasma homocysteine concentrations in healthy volunteers: a randomized trial. Am J Clin Nutr. 2000 Feb;71(2):480-4.

Ma Y, Peng D, Liu C, Huang C, Luo J. Serum high concentrations of homocysteine and low levels of folic acid and vitamin B(12) are significantly correlated with the categories of coronary artery diseases. BMC Cardiovasc Disord. 2017 Jan 21;17(1):37. doi: 10.1186/s12872-017-0475-8.
